related_questions.question: What is considered an affiliate company?
related_questions.snippet: The definition of “affiliated company” will vary, depending on the context in which the term is used. One way that companies are considered affiliated is when one company owns less than the majority interest in another company. Companies also may be affiliated when they are subsidiaries of a third company.

related_questions.question: Is an affiliate an employee?
related_questions.snippet: Definition of Affiliate Employee. Affiliate Employee means any Employee who is an officer or director of the Company. Affiliate Employee means any person employed by an Affiliate.

related_questions.question: What is the difference between affiliate and non affiliate?
related_questions.snippet: In most cases, affiliate and associate are used synonymously to describe a company whose parent only possesses a minority stake in the ownership of the company. However, a subsidiary is a business whose parent holds a majority stake or is a majority shareholder of 50% or more of all shares.Apr 14, 2019

related_questions.question: Is an affiliate a separate legal entity?
related_questions.snippet: Affiliates Versus Subsidiaries But subsidiaries remain separate legal entities from their parents, meaning they are liable for their own taxes, liabilities, and governance. ... An example of a subsidiary is the relationship between the Walt Disney Corporation and sports network ESPN.Jun 1, 2019

answer_box.title: Affiliate dictionary definition | affiliate defined - YourDictionary
answer_box.snippet: affiliate - Legal Definition n. A corporation that is related to another corporation by one owning shares of the other, by common ownership, or by other means of control. See also company (parent) and subsidiary.

organic_results.title: Affiliates Law and Legal Definition | USLegal, Inc.
organic_results.snippet: Affiliates Law and Legal Definition. Affiliates are business concerns, organizations, or individuals that control each other or that are controlled by a third party. Control may consist of shared management or ownership; common use of facilities, equipment, and employees; or family interest.
